{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3568164,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T17:02:04.200Z","cooked":"

Connected the dots on this issue today:

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

Pose estimator doesn't update odometry pose with vision measurements over time, leading to drift

opened 04:11PM - 25 Mar 25 UTC
calcmogul
type: bug component: wpimath

Initially reported by FRC team 2363: Step 9 of `PoseEstimator.addVisionMeasurem…ent()` sets the PoseEstimator pose estimate to a vision-compensated version of the latest odometry object pose, but the odometry object's pose is only updated by twists passed to `PoseEstimator.updateWithTime()`. This means the odometry pose is still allowed to drift over time instead of being gradually fixed by vision measurements. In other words, the odometry is only ever getting fixed by one vision measurement instead of a backlog of all of them. The old implementation applied vision updates to old pose estimates, then replayed odometry updates up to the current time. That was too expensive at the time, so idk if we can fix this properly. The odometry object pose not being vision-compensated also causes `PoseEstimator.resetRotation()` to make the translation estimate teleport from the vision-compensated version to the odometry-only version.

If you’re having pose estimator convergence issues that isn’t fixed by throwing more vision measurements at it, this is probably why. Reverting to the 2024 version has the “proper” fix (replaying old odometry updates), but it was too expensive for the roboRIO to handle.

This affects CTRE’s pose estimator as well, since it’s based on WPILib’s 2025 pose estimator.

Thank you for finding this. It explains something we have been stumped on for a while.

If I’m understanding correctly, the odometry pose is just going to be wrong after just 30 seconds to driving, and the vision is trying it’s darn best to pull the pose to be correct but it’s having to fight extremely hard since odometry is never actually corrected? With that in mind, I’m genuinely confused how we are able to drive for close to an hour and notice no difference in vision performance.

If we are using a RoboRIO 2, would the suggested change be to use the 2024 pose estimator?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T17:35:28.482Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":350,"readers_count":349,"score":89.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496876,"topic_slug":"psa-wpilib-pose-estimator-drifts-and-ignores-most-vision-measurements","display_username":"Will Weiszhaar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65296,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/psa-wpilib-pose-estimator-drifts-and-ignores-most-vision-measurements/496876/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3568248,"name":"Jared Russell","username":"Jared_Russell","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jared_russell/{size}/399_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T17:53:17.233Z","cooked":"

I don’t see a big problem?

The consequence of not updating past odometry measurements is just that m_odometry is free to drift over time and never gets corrected in itself.

This is a totally valid choice of problem definition (and is the way ROS’s robot pose EKF and many other implementations define it): odometry happens in its own odometric reference frame that is never updated by vision, and instead vision is used to update a transform mapping the odometric frame into a global frame rather than updating the pose estimate itself.

Vision doesn’t have to “fight” odometry, because when we process a vision update we already correct the prior odometry pose estimate using the previous (fused) vision update, then compute a twist based on that. The new twist is basically “how much the odom-to-global transform has moved since the last vision update”, which is the appropriate thing to multiply by Kalman gain.

I think the only thing we’re losing by not updating the odom pose history is the ability to account for the odom-to-global transform not being stationary over time: implicitly, the current implementation is treating vision updates with a zero-order hold: “Aha, I now know the truth is I’ve always been here!” as opposed to “Well, I know I’m here now but a little bit ago I may have been somewhere else”. There can be subtle differences in how you integrate past odometry under different assumptions, but I doubt they are actually consequential in the common case in FRC (vision updates lagging odometry by a couple hundred ms worst case).
